Award.AbstractNarration:
The Trojan Express Network II (TEN-II) project at the University of Southern California (USC) builds on existing network infrastructure to provide the next generation of network services. TEN-II enables significant new scientific research and education opportunities for multiple departments and research groups. Examples include projects that need access to large data flows from remote instruments, transfer of large data sets to or from national computing centers or cloud-based providers, and multi-institutional research and education collaborations that rely on the transfer of large data sets between partners in a timely and reliable manner.

Scientific research and education continues to be ever more data and compute intensive, and the demand for higher performance and more reliable data transfer will continue to grow over the next decade. The project is deploying a parallel network over existing fiber infrastructure to provide high data-rate services to at least 6 research laboratories across 3 facilities of the university that are geographically dispersed around Los Angeles. The network is operated using Software Defined Networking (SDN) technology and provides access to the campus high-performance computing facility and to other institutions over regional, national, and international advanced research and education networks. TEN-II authenticates the use of the infrastructure based on users' credentials that are currently used to access other IT services and interfaces with similar mechanisms under development by regional and national networks.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Research is becoming ever more data and compute intensive. Researchers need to transfer massive amounts of data between collaborators or between their laboratory and a computational facility, either on their campus or to national computational centers and data repositories, or to specialized equipment and facilities. High-definition visualization may rely on real-time data transfers from similar facilities with data rates of hundreds of megabits or gigabits per second. Current campus networks and the general purpose Internet are not designed to deliver at these data rates. National and Regional Research and Education Networks (RENs) have recognized these challenges and are deploying 100 Gbps backbones that have the ability to dynamically allocate virtual circuits to support high data-rate flows. For researchers to gain access to these connections, and to enable high-performance computer center and digital data repositories, a high-performance campus network is necessary.

In this project, the University of Southern California has deployed a persistent high-performance network built on 10 and 100 gigabit per second links and switched using software-defined networking technology.  This new network, called TEN-II (Trojan Express Network II) builds on existing cyberinfrastructure including USC's Center for High-Performance Computing (HPC) Center,  the Los Nettos regional network, the Corporation for Education Network Initiatives in California (CENIC) High-Performance research Network (HPR), and Internet 2's Advanced Layer 2 Service (AL2S);.  The network provides services to the main USC campuses (the University Park Campus (UPC), the Health Sciences Campus (HSC), and the Information Sciences Institute(ISI),  serving several research laboratories spanning multiple science domains, including cyber-defense and security, social sciences, geological sciences, geophysical sciences, geochemical sciences, materials

By providing USC researchers with access to high performance network connections and fostering inter-institutional collaborations, TEN-II expects to enable our researchers and their collaborators to develop science and educational opportunities that they would not otherwise have been able to achieve.  Two examples of these are: marine biology digital microscopy collaboration enabling a high school in Tennessee to use a high definition digital microscope located at the University as part of a high school biology class, and the Visual History Institute archives of living testimonies from survivors of the holocaust which are used in many research and education contexts.

TEN-II has been integrated into the persistent network infrastructure at USC and can be expanded to other facilities as needed.
